docs.lead_paragraph: Early confidence in the law’s constitutionality, based on Supreme Court precedents, proved to be a miscalculation that put the White House on the defensive as its legal strategy evolved over the last two years.

headline.seo: Past Denials of Vulnerability Raise Health Act What-Ifs
headline.main: Supporters Slow to Grasp Health Law’s Legal Risks
headline.print_headline: Supporters Slow to Grasp Health Law’s Legal Risks

docs.abstract: Early confidence in the constitutionality of the Affordable Care Act, based on Supreme Court precedents, proved to be a miscalculation that put the White House on the defensive as its legal strategy evolved over the last two years; Pres Obama is now reckoning with the possibility that the legislative centerpiece of his administration may be partly or completely overturned.
docs.snippet: Early confidence in the law’s constitutionality, based on Supreme Court precedents, proved to be a miscalculation that put the White House on the defensive as its legal strategy evolved over the last two years.

docs.lead_paragraph: While consumers tend to think of Apple’s headquarters as the company’s heart and soul, a majority of its workers in the United States are hourly wage earners selling iPhones and MacBooks.

headline.seo: Apple Stores’ Army, Long on Loyalty but Short on Pay
headline.main: Apple’s Retail Army, Long on Loyalty but Short on Pay
headline.print_headline: Apple’s Retail Army, Long on Loyalty but Short on Pay

docs.abstract: Apple Stores, renowned for impeccable design, deft service and spectacular revenues, rely on a massive retail work force that enjoys little of the company's astounding wealth; about 30,000 of Apple's 43,000 employees work in Apple Stores where many of them earn about $25,000 per year (Series: The iEconomy).
docs.snippet: While consumers tend to think of Apple’s headquarters as the company’s heart and soul, a majority of its workers in the United States are hourly wage earners selling iPhones and MacBooks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Though optimistic in public, the White House in private is weighing its options in case the Supreme Court invalidates all or part of the health care law.

headline.seo: White House Waits Tensely for Decision on Health Law
headline.main: Wearing Brave Face, Obama Braces for Health Care Ruling
headline.print_headline: Putting On a Brave Face, but Preparing for Heartbreak on Health Care

docs.abstract: White House memo; White House, though optimistic in public, in private is weighing its options in case the Supreme Court invalidates all or part of the health care law; court's decision on what is seen as Pres Obama's most profound policy achievement will help determine whether he is the game-changing president he aspired to be.
docs.snippet: Though optimistic in public, the White House in private is weighing its options in case the Supreme Court invalidates all or part of the health care law.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite the increasing sophistication of today’s youth, fewer of them are leaving home to lead independent lives after college.

headline.seo: Offspring Who Cling to the Nest
headline.main: Offspring Who Cling to the Nest
headline.print_headline: Offspring Who Cling To the Nest

docs.abstract: Ginia Bellafante Big City column asserts that the upbringing of affluent children in New York City is subject to a conflicted parental desire for both heightened sophistication and advanced attachment; contends that the line between the phases of childhood and adulthood is becoming increasingly blurred in city's urbane families, with fewer offspring leaving home to lead independent lives after college.
docs.snippet: Despite the increasing sophistication of today’s youth, fewer of them are leaving home to lead independent lives after college.

docs.lead_paragraph: And what it took to get him the help he needed.

headline.main: When My Crazy Father Actually Lost His Mind

docs.abstract: Jeneen Interlandi describes her family's experiences dealing with her father's increasingly troublesome mental illness; observes that families across the United States struggle with mentally ill family members as state mental health programs fall to budget cutbacks and in the face of a national dearth of psychiatric hospitals.
docs.snippet: And what it took to get him the help he needed.

docs.lead_paragraph: He was one of those salt-of-the-earth guys from the rural part of Pennsylvania. Middle-aged, married with adult kids, he'd worked his whole life running his own small business, a local restaurant that he jokingly called a bordello. His wife worked, too, and she had health insurance, but he wasn't on her policy. Maybe he couldn't afford it, or he was saving money by playing the odds. After all, he'd always been healthy. And then one day he had leukemia. I was his nurse, and he surprised me one afternoon by bringing up ''death panels.'' Usually I avoid having political conversations in the hospital, but he was preoccupied with something that wasn't real. I didn't want him worrying about a chimera when he was adjusting to a diagnosis of cancer and an inpatient hospital stay that would last six weeks or more.
docs.abstract: Bedside column by oncology nurse Theresa Brown contends that if the health care reform law is overturned by the Supreme Court, those with insurance will continue to subsidize the uninsured in the form of higher premiums and increased out-of-pocket costs and deductibles; asserts that although the law may not be the best solution, it prevents those with tough diagnoses from having to choose between their money or their life. (M)
